para.paratext: Under O.C.G.A. §§ 24-6-607 and 24-6-608, evidence of the character of a witness in a civil action is not admissible unless character is a material issue in the case.[1] Georgia law follows this rule,[2] but allows more exceptions than most jurisdictions. The most frequently applied exception is the use of character evidence for the purpose of impeachment.

Unlike many other states, Georgia courts admit character evidence if the party in a civil action is sued for conduct which may be considered criminal or involves moral turpitude.[3] For example, in Dalton v. Jackson,[4] the plaintiff filed a civil action against the defendant for damages from an alleged rape. At trial, the defendant offered the testimony of sixteen witnesses to prove the defendant's good character. The Georgia Court of Appeals held that the character evidence was properly admitted due to the nature of the case. Similarly, evidence of a defendant's good character in a civil fraud case will be admitted.[5] The Court of Appeals also upheld the admissibility of evidence of a physician's note where the trial court found the jury could reasonably decide whether a physician's note involved deliberate deception or rather was simply a mistake.[6]

On the other hand, evidence of a party's good character was not admissible in an automobile liability case. The fact that each party took the position that the light was green as they proceeded through the intersection did not constitute an attack on opposing party's character for truthfulness sufficient to open the door for such evidence.[7]

The general rule excluding character evidence may not apply if the evidence is relevant for a purpose other than to prove a party's propensity to act in a certain way. Although inadmissible in a civil case on the issue of liability, character evidence may be relevant and admissible on the issue of general and punitive damages. Thus, the plaintiff in a wrongful death case may properly admit evidence of the decedent's character to the extent that such evidence assists the jury in determining life expectancy, career potential, and “the intangible element of the full value of the life of the deceased” necessary to award damages.[8] Character evidence may also be admitted on the issue of punitive damages to prove the defendant's conscious indifference to consequences.[9]

Generally, evidence of a party's other acts or that a person experienced a similar accident, event, or transaction will not be admissible to prove a propensity toward such accidents or a history of negligent behavior.[10] The proffering party must show that the similar happening has some relevancy,[11] such as connection in time.[12]
In negligence actions, evidence of a party's other acts of negligence is not admissible.[13] A party's conduct in an incident may be proved only by the facts of that incident.

A party's previous acts or general character for carelessness are not probative of the issue of negligence and may be prejudicial before the jury.[14] Thus, in Leo v. Williams,[15] the Georgia Court of Appeals reversed the trial court's decision to allow defendant to introduce evidence of plaintiff's past traffic violations in a case involving an automobile collision. In reversing, the court held that a party's negligence cannot be proved by evidence of his prior driving record or general character for carelessness or recklessness.

Also, transactions between different parties, are inadmissible.[16] For example, it was reversible error for a defendant physician to testify that he had never been sued in a medical malpractice case.[17]

However, evidence concerning a plaintiff's other injuries may be admissible to show that the injuries at issue are not the result of defendant's alleged negligence though evidence of a plaintiff's prior personal injury action is not relevant.[18]
Housing Authority of Atlanta v. Green, 169 Ga. App. 211, 312 S.E.2d 196 (1983) (citing U. S. Shoe Corp. v. Jones, 149 Ga. App. 595, 255 S.E.2d 73 (1979)).
Stanley v. Hudson, 78 Ga. App. 834, 52 S.E.2d 567 (1949); Stanley v. Willingham, 93 Ga. App. 421, 91 S.E.2d 791 (1956); Ginsberg v. Termotto, 175 Ga. App. 265, 333 S.E.2d 120 (1985).
Conley v. Conley, 152 Ga. 184, 108 S.E. 777 (1921); Mays v. Mays, 153 Ga. 835, 113 S.E. 154 (1922); Dalton v. Jackson, 66 Ga. App. 625, 18 S.E.2d 791 (1942).
See also Housing Authority of Atlanta v. Green, 169 Ga. App. 211, 312 S.E.2d 196 (1983).
“Evidence of a threat to commit an unlawful act involves a question of character which may be refuted by evidence of good character.” Hogan v. Hogan, 196 Ga. 822, 28 S.E.2d 74 (1943).
Dalton v. Jackson, 66 Ga. App. 625, 18 S.E.2d 791 (1942).
Wimberly v. Toney, 175 Ga. 416, 165 S.E. 257 (1932); Caldwell v. Caldwell, 59 Ga. App. 637, 1 S.E.2d 764 (1939).

However, evidence of good character standing alone will not be enough to support a verdict against positive evidence of fraud. See Lawler v. Life Ins. Co. of Ga., 90 Ga. App. 481, 83 S.E.2d 281 (1954), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 211 Ga. 246, 85 S.E.2d 1 (1954).
Central Georgia Women's Health Center, LLC v. Dean, 342 Ga. App. 127, 800 S.E.2d 594 (2017).
Barnett v. Farmer, 308 Ga. App. 358, 359, 707 S.E.2d 570 (2011).

Consolidated Freightways Corp. of Delaware v. Futrell, 201 Ga. App. 233, 234, 410 S.E.2d 751 (1991) (evidence of a decedent's church activities and religious beliefs may be relevant as an aspect of the intangible element of the full value of the life of a deceased).

But see Taylor v. RaceTrac Petroleum, Inc., 238 Ga. App. 761, 519 S.E.2d 282 (1999) (evidence of decedent's drug prior drug and alcohol use, alleged reckless driving on other occasions and alleged violent acts on other occasions were irrelevant to the question of liability for the accident in this case and were also not probative of life expectancy or earning capacity because such conduct was not shown to be frequent or habitual); Key v. Grant, 238 Ga. App. 818, 520 S.E.2d 277 (1999) (evidence of criminal record was not relevant to the full value of the deceased's life); Brock v. Wedincamp, 253 Ga. App. 275, 558 S.E.2d 836 (2002) (trial court could not properly admit evidence of the decedent's abortions, adoptions, or sex life merely because the plaintiff presented some evidence that the decedent “was a good mother, or a good person, or liked or wanted to work with children”; such evidence was irrelevant to damages and “inflammatory”).
See Webster v. Boyett, 269 Ga. 191, 496 S.E.2d 459 (1998); Craig v. Holsey, 264 Ga. App. 344, 590 S.E.2d 742 (2003).

However, because such evidence is generally irrelevant to the issue of liability, trial should be bifurcated or trifurcated into liability and damage phases. Leo v. Williams, 207 Ga. App. 321, 428 S.E.2d 108 (1993). See also Webster v. Boyett, 269 Ga. 191, 496 S.E.2d 459 (1998), holding that as a result of the punitive damage bifurcation procedure codified in O.C.G.A. § 51-12-5.1, courts must use their discretion to either bifurcate or trifurcate a trial when punitive damages are at stake.
O.C.G.A. § 24-4-404: “Evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts shall not be admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith.”
As held in Sparks v. Pine Forest Enterprises, Inc., 174 Ga. App. 598, 331 S.E.2d 34 (1985), the prior happening must be sufficiently similar to the one in question to be relevant.
Tidwell v. Lovejoy, 94 Ga. App. 60, 94 S.E.2d 39 (1956), judgment rev'd on other grounds, 212 Ga. 750, 95 S.E.2d 784 (1956).

Smith v. Morning News, Inc., 99 Ga. App. 547, 109 S.E.2d 639 (1959); Seaboard Coast Line R. Co. v. Clark, 122 Ga. App. 237, 176 S.E.2d 596 (1970); Flowers v. Slash Pine Elec. Membership Corp., 122 Ga. App. 254, 176 S.E.2d 542 (1970); Hulsey v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 138 Ga. App. 523, 226 S.E.2d 791 (1976); White v. Seaboard Coast Line R. Co., 139 Ga. App. 833, 229 S.E.2d 775 (1976).
Royal v. Ferrellgas, Inc., 254 Ga. App. 696, 563 S.E.2d 451 (2002).
Leo v. Williams, 207 Ga. App. 321, 428 S.E.2d 108 (1993).
Merchants' Nat. Bank of Rome v. Greenwood, 113 Ga. 306, 38 S.E. 826 (1901).
Williams v. Naidu, 168 Ga. App. 539, 309 S.E.2d 686 (1983).
Kilday v. Kennestone Physicians Center, L.P., 296 Ga. App. 818, 676 S.E.2d 271 (2009).
